title: Bond ETFs fall ahead of expected Fed rate hike; Bond ETFs that invest in Treasurys and corporate debt are slumping as investors await outcome of Fed meeting
text:
Shares of the iShares 20+ Year Treasury Bond ETF TLT were down around 1.2%, while the iShares iBoxx $ Investment Grade Corporate Bond ETF LQD fell 1.1% and the iShares Boxx $ High Yield Corporate Bond ETF HYG dropped 1%, according to FactSet data, at last check.

Treasury yields have surged again in recent weeks as investors fear the Fed will keep up its aggressive pace of monetary tightening in an effort to bring stubbornly high inflation under control. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y was up around 9 basis points at 3.57% Tuesday afternoon, FactSet data show, at last check. That's after climbing Monday to its highest yield since April 12, 2011 based on 3 p.m. Eastern time levels, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

Read: Why rising Treasury yields are a drag on the stock market

Meanwhile, shares of iShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond ETF AGG were down 0.5% Tuesday afternoon, while the iShares 7-10 Year Treasury Bond ETF IEF fell 0.7% and the iShares 1-3 Year Treasury Bond SHY dipped less than 0.1%, FactSet data show, at last check.

Shares of the iShares TIPS Bond ETF TIP, which provides exposure to Treasury inflation-protected securities, were also trading lower, down about 0.2%.

Read: This interest-rate-hedge ETF has soared 60% this year as stocks, bonds sink in market carnage

Bonds have taken a hit along with equities this year amid rising rates and the hottest inflation in decades. For example, the iShares 20+ Year Treasury Bond ETF has lost 26.6% in 2022 through Monday on a total return basis, while the iShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond ETF had a 12.3% loss over the same period.

The U.S. stock market was down Tuesday afternoon, with the S&P 500 SPX falling 1.1% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA dropping more than 300 points amid concern over rising rates and high inflation, FactSet data show, at last check. The S&P 500 has tumbled 18% this year through Monday.
